DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0809 to fix dateline
Electoral Court Confirms Collor de Mello's Win in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday confirmed Fernando Collor de Mello, a conservative who advocates a free-market economy, as winner of Brazil's first free presidential election in 29 years. Collor de Mello, a 40-year-old native of Rio de Janeiro and head of the rightist National Reconstruction Party, had 34,698,234 votes, or 42.74 percent, after 98.9 percent of the votes had been tallied, Supreme Electoral Court spokesman Irineu Tamanini said. His socialist rival, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva of the radical left Workers Party, received 30,929,253 votes, 38.10 per cent. Da Silva conceded he had lost late Wednesday. Tamanini said 1.2 percent of the ballots were blank, 3.81 percent were annulled and 14.15 percent were abstentions. Voting is mandatory for Brazilians aged 18 to 69. Tamanini said the final vote count wouldn't be announced until Thursday because torrential rain in northern Brazil delayed the transfer of ballot boxes from the Amazon states of Para and Amapa to Brasilia, the federal capital. The Court would officially announce Collor de Mello the winner on Dec. 29, he said. The president-elect is scheduled to take office Mar. 15, 1990, for a five-year term. He will succeed Jose Sarney, who by law cannot run for re-election.
